On 28 February 2019, Nyang'au villagers carried out an attack on a family suspected of practising witchcraft and torched their five houses. Six people died in the attack in Rongo constituency, Migori county. [size=no report]
27 February: Kenyan police killed two armed men who were transporting illegal ammunition in West Pokot County.
27 February: A civilian was shot and killed by 'bandits' while herding his livestock in Kambi in West Pokot, on the Kainuk-Kapenguria road (approx coordinates used). No looting reported.
27 February: A woman was shot and killed and another - a shopkeeper- shot and injured by unknown 'bandits' in Sultan Hamud town. No looting reported.
27 February: A civilian shot dead by armed men in Kainuk in retliation for an earlier attack on a herder in Kambi.
24 February: Trans Nzoia farmers held demonstration over the delays in purchase of their products by National Cereals and Produce Board due to lack of bags for storage [size=no report]
22 February: Migori residents protested over the rising insecurity and the inability of Kenyan police to tackle criminality in Kenya
On Feb 21st 2019, Sosio villagers set on fire 7 houses belonging to a man who confessed to have mutilated a 9-year-old child, allegedly for witchcraft. [size=no report]
20 February: Litein residents protested over the rising insecurity. They expressed feelings of insecurity and their loss of trust in Kenyan police to protect them from the gangs
16 February: Three people including a police officer died in clashes between Pokot and Turkana communties in Kainuk.
12 February: Nairobi workers held a demonstration over the country's failure to increase their salary by 15%.

On February 07, the body of a missing human rights activist was found in the city mortuary. Date and location of killing unclear. Some medias say that she died from excessive bleeding as a result of botched abortion in a clinic.
07 February: A member of Kenyan police raped a 13 years old girl. [women targeted: girls]
02 February: Two dead bodies were found on the Kikuyu road. No group has claimed responsibility yet
02 February: Residents around Kitale-Eldoret highway protested against land grabbing
01 February: Taita Taveta county nurses protested over poor medical equipmrnt and understaffing in public health centers
01 February: Eldoret residents protested against the killing of civilians by police officers.
On Feb 1st 2019, residents of Eldoret protested against the accidental release of three men suspected to have killed a boda boda driver. [size=no report]
31 January: Unidentified gunmen killed a civilian in Mombasa
30 January: Unidentified gunmen abducted and killed a civilian in Wote, Makueni county.
30 January (on or around): A woman went missing. Her body was found in the city mortuary in Kariobangi South on February 4th. No group has claimed a responsibility yet
On Jan 30th residents of Gitaru blocked the Gitaru-Wangige road, attempting to prevent Forest Service officers from seizing logs that they had cut from their farms. [size=no report]
24 January: Police killed a suspected thief. The residents insisted he was an innocent man who was a victim of extrajudicial killing
23 January: In Muruka village, a civilian was shot and wounded by a police officer who was mad after his favourite football team lost. He later died in the hospital
23 January: In Kajiado sub-county, Nkatataek mixed secondary school students' parents protested against the school's adminstration
22 January: In Nariobi, Kenya, University students held demonstration over increased extrajudicial killings of students by police.

21 January: In Mau Narok, Nakuru county, two farmers were injured in an attak carried out by suspected Maasai ethnic militias. Maasai tribe members have been complaining that the farm was taken away from their ancestors and want to get it back.
21 January: Eldoret farmers protested over NCPB (National Cereals and Produce Board) failure to buy maize from them even though president Uhuru had ordered them to buy
21 January : In Mau Narok trading center, youths lit bonfires and barricaded the Njoro-Mau Narok road to protest the attack against farmers earlier that day.
19 January: Two people were injured when suspected IED went off outside a restaurant in Nairobi.
19 January: In West Pokot county, an armed bandit shot and killed a 10 year old child.

15-16 January: Al Shabaab militants attacked the DusitD2 hotel in Westlands, Nairobi using hand grenades, guns, suicide bombings and blowing up vehicles. Soldiers and police reacted with gunfire. 21 people total (including the attackers, civilians and one member of security forces) were killed in the attack. It is not clear if the al Shabaab fatalities were due to suicide bombings or the security response. 28 others were injured. The attack began on the afternoon of the 15th and carried into the following day. One American and one Briton were among the dead.

15-16 January: Al Shabaab militants attacked the DusitD2 hotel in Westlands, Nairobi using hand grenades, guns, suicide bombings and blowing up vehicles. Soldiers and police reacted with gunfire. 21 people total (including the attackers, civilians and one member of security forces) were killed in the attack. It is not clear if the al Shabaab fatalities were due to suicide bombings or the security response. 28 others were injured. The attack began on the afternoon of the 15th and carried into the following day. One American and one Briton were among the dead.

15-16 January: Al Shabaab militants attacked the DusitD2 hotel in Westlands, Nairobi using hand grenades, guns, suicide bombings and blowing up vehicles. Soldiers and police reacted with gunfire. 21 people total (including the attackers, civilians and one member of security forces) were killed in the attack. It is not clear if the al Shabaab fatalities were due to suicide bombings or the security response. 28 others were injured. The attack began on the afternoon of the 15th and carried into the following day. One American and one Briton were among the dead.

15-16 January: Al Shabaab militants attacked the DusitD2 hotel in Westlands, Nairobi using hand grenades, guns, suicide bombings and blowing up vehicles. Soldiers and police reacted with gunfire. 21 people total (including the attackers, civilians and one member of security forces) were killed in the attack. It is not clear if the al Shabaab fatalities were due to suicide bombings or the security response. 28 others were injured. The attack began on the afternoon of the 15th and carried into the following day. One American and one Briton were among the dead.
On 15 January 2019, taxi and mutatu drivers demonstrated against the bad road condition in Nyeri (Nyeri Town, Nyeri). They burned tyres and put banana leaves on the road. [size=no report]
On 14 January 2019, sugar cane farmers protested in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the the lack of representation in new sugar task force. [size=no report]
12 January: Narok residents held a demonstration against the authorities over increasing road accidents
11 January: In Bomet county, Konoin, one civilian was found dead in a tea farm. No group has claimed responsibility.

09 January: In Makeuni county, Wote residents protested against the death of a 16 year old kid, claiming that he was bewitched by a woman. Protesters demanded the woman to ressurect the kid but they were dispersed by police.

09 January: In Usasin Gisha county, millers in Eldoret city protested against the order to vacate NCPB (National Cereals and Produce Board) store. They had been using the store for 18 years prior to the order
On 5 January 2019, residents demonstrated over poor state road condition in Kahawa (Roysambu, Nairobi). [size=no report]
On 5 January 2019, water vendors in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) protested against the new directive by the county administration to desalinate all salty water. [size=no report]
On 3 January 2019, residents demonstrated against abusive fares of the Matatu private minibus in Homa Bay town (Homa Bay, Homa Bay). [size=no report]
02 January: Nzoia Sugar Company Acting Managing Director Michael Kulundu was kidnapped in Kanduyi. He was tortured to death later.
01 January: Kenya police shot dead one civilian in Mombasa, Kenya. Circumstances unclear.
On 1 January 2019, residents demonstrated in Kendu Bay (Karachuonyo, Homa Bay) against a project that will harvest massive sand from the shores of the Lake Victoria. [size=no report]
29 December: Two children were killed by explosive devices while herding in Samburu. No group has claimed responsibility
28 December: In likoni, Mombasa county, two men were killed by Bodaboda operators on suspicion of belonging to a criminal gang.
27 December: In Kibera town, people demonstrated demanding justice for a student killed by a police officer. Police dispersed the protesters

On 27 December 2018, people in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) protested against police brutality following the death of a man in custody of police officials. Police responded with live fire, injuring two. [size=no report]
25 December: In Bondo town, the west Yimbo chief, Daniel Tiang was found dead at a guest house, likely by poison.

actor2: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Border Patrol Unit
notes: 25 December: unknown gunmen threw a grenade at a Kenya border police patrol, leaving some injured in Mandera town.
25 December: Al Shabaab claimed to have killed two Kenyan police and injured three others in Mandera town.
24 December: Boda Boada riders beat to death the Embu Governor Wambora's body guard (assumed unarmed) over a fare dispute in Embu county. Exact location unknown
22 December: Police allegedly shot and killed a 23 year-old university student claimig that he was a member of a gang that was terrorising Line Saba residents
20 December: In Siakago, Embu County, unidentified armed group attacked a 15 years old boy. They chopped off his private part and left him with deep cut on his head as well.
19 December: Kayole residents protested for the second day as Nyama villa estate demolitions continued. Tens of families left homeless
18 December: In Kayole, residents protested against the demolition of Nyama Villa estate.
17 December: Members of Kenya Defense Forces clashed with Al Shabaab members trying to plant an explosive device at Bodhei, Lamu County. No casualties reported.

16 December: Kolongolo village community threw stones and other objects at police officers in Kwanza while police opened fire on the crowd. Five killed. The community came to the rescue of a man being roughed up by police officers to the point of undressing him in public after he refused to be arrested.

On December 14th or 15th, clashes erupted in Ololoipangi, Nkoben and Oloruasi in Narok South in the area of Olololunga. One elderly man was killed, and up to eight people injured, seemingly with arrows. The clashes follows violence in September between the Maasai and Kipsigi groups (who have been coded as the actors for this event).

On December 14th or 15th, clashes erupted in Ololoipangi, Nkoben and Oloruasi in Narok South in the area of Olololunga. One elderly man was killed, and up to eight people injured, seemingly with arrows. The clashes follows violence in September between the Maasai and Kipsigi groups (who have been coded as the actors for this event).
On 14 December 2018, police reservists shot and wounded a man as he attempted to break into a house in Mandera town.

actor1: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Rapid Deployment Unit
notes: On or around December 13th, 14 police from the Rapid Deployment Unit at Kapedo entered Mandera police station in order to release a colleague who was being held for robbery with violence. The Kapedo police fired in the air - and held the Madera police commander hostage -whilst they released the detained officer from the cells, before walking back to Kapedo. No injuries were reported.

On 13 December 2018, a vigilante mob attacked and killed a gang member (who was a former police officer) in Vumale village (coordinates for Kegoye, Vihiga, used) who was attempting to flee the area after a botched robbery. Three other gang members escaped.

On 13 December 2018, demonstrators gathered at the Kitui County Assembly, ostensibly to protest against elements of the assembly blocking development projects in the area (note that the source indicates the demonstrators were supporters of the Governor of Kitui, and the event is described as being enmeshed in a dispute over the allocation of resources and impropriety). The demonstrators barricaded the entrance to the assembly, before battling with armed police, who used tear gas to disperse them.

On 12 December 2018, unknown gunmen shot dead the former deputy governor of Kilifi outside his house in Nyali (Mombasa) in the presence of his security guard. The gunmen were reported to have been attempting to rob the victim, and proceeded to rob his security guard of Ksh 6,000.

On 11 December 2018, a group of locals and refugees in Kakuma Refugee Camp (Turkana West, Turkana) beat up refugees accused of being gay with wooden sticks and iron bars when they were protesting outside the UNHCR office against rising homophobic attacks in recent months. About 20 refugees were injured. [size=no report]
On 11 December 2018, a gang attacked an unspecified location in the Kegoye sub-county (Vihiga county), wounding four people (who suffered head wounds). There are no further details.

On 11 December 2018, LGBT refugees protested against homophobic attacks in the Kakuma Refugee camp (Turkana West, Turkana). The protesters were then beaten with sticks and iron bars (wounding 20), by both Kenyan citizens as well as fellow refugees (note that the nationality of the refugees is not provided; accordingly no associate actors are coded as IDPs/Refugees). The UNHCR has begun the process of permanently relocating LGBT refugees from the camp to Nairobi. [size=no report]
On 10 December 2018, an armed gang comprising four men shot dead a priest as he was travelling to Kikuyu town (Kiambu county), and stole donations that had been made to the priest the previous day.

On 10 December 2018, two sections of the Lou Nuer clashed in the Kakuma Refugee camp (Turkana), reportedly over a girl who had been impregnated. Two people were reported to have died, and eight (seemingly civilians) were injured, one seriously. The source does not specify which weapons were used in the incident, if any.
On or around December 8th, an armed gang (wearing police uniforms) robbed a petrol station in Mandera town, killing a security guard in the process. Police are investigating.
On 8 December 2018, three civilians were injured when their lorry was hit by an IED near Sankuri (Lamu county). The device was suspected to have been planted by Al Shabaab.

On 7 December 2018, traders demonstrating against the recent arrest of their colleagues clashed with police at Voi (Taita Taveta). The source describes police and traders as engaging in running battles, with the traders barricading Voi Town road, and police firing tear gas at the traders.
On or around December 6th, two local government officials were ambushed and killed by suspected raiders from West Pokot, as they travelled from Kapelbok (Turkana, coordinates used) to Nakwamoru.
On 6 December 2018, police and two gang members exchanged gunfire at Kayole (Nairobi). One gang member died in the exchange, another fled the scene.

On 5 December 2018, a gang described as being cattle rustlers attacked Koibirir location in the Elegeyo area. The attackers injured several villagers, and stole cattle. There are no further details on the event.
On 5 December 2018, police clashed with rioting football fans at Lamu. The violence followed the defeat of a football team participating in a four day long Maulid festival.

On 5 December 2018, an unknown group attacked Takaywa (note: unclear if Takaywa is on the West Pokot or Turkana side of the border. Coordinates for Lokichar, Turkana, have been used, at precision 3), killing a child, and stealing an unknown number of cattle. One source indicates the attack took place at Karon, in North Pokot sub-county.

On 3 December 2018, students demonstrated in Mombasa against the impostion of what are described as 'tough sudden rules' by the University of Mombasa administration. The students blockaded roads and damaged vehicles, and then threw stones at police, who responded by firing live rounds in the air, dispersing the demonstrators.

On or around November 30th, youth groups fought in Bungoma, seemingly over a local political dispute. Police dispersed the rioters using tear gas and live rounds. A number of youth were reported to have been injured in the clashes.
On or before November 29th, police fired shots at anti-corruption police who came to arrest two regular police office as part of a sting operation in Nairobi.
On 29 November 2018, around 500 traders protested in Taveta (Taita Taveta) against the imposition of significantly higher taxes on produce in the county. The traders marched to the county offices.
On 29 November 2018, boda boda (motorcycle taxis) drivers demonstrated in Kericho, resulting in clashes between the drivers and police, reportedly for several hours.

During the week beginning November 26th, herders assaulted a farmer at Banita (Nakuru). The farmer claimed the group wanted him to vacate the land. The event is part of a spate of similar incidents in the area.

During the week beginning November 26th, raiders (suspected of coming from Masol village in West Pokot) attacked the village of Kaakong (Turkana), killing a child, and stealing 150 goats. One source indicates that two people were killed in the attack; two sources suggest the event took place in the following week (time precision of 2 used).

On 29 November 2018, bandits attacked a group of herders at Lobua near Gambela (coordinates for Gambela, Wajir, used), killing one, and wounding two. The bandits then stole 16 cows. The source notes that bandits were suspected of belonging to the Turkana ethnic group, though this has not been confirmed.

On or before November 27th, students from Moi Univeristy (Usain Gishu) went 'on rampage', blocking the Eldoret-Nakuru highway, in protest at the delayed release of marks, and delays in graduation. Police dispersed them.

On 27 November 2018, police shot dead two suspected gang members and wounded a third at an unspecified location along the Nakuru-Nairobi highway (coordinates for Nakuru town used). The gang had stolen a lorry, and were being pursued by the police. The injured gang member is at large.

On 26 November 2018, motorbike taxi drivers blocked a road and attempted to remove a police block in the area of Kiguchwa (Isiolo), to demonstrate against a concerted effort by police to improve safety standards. The demonstrators were joined by a local MP, who was later arrested.

On 24 November 2018, a gang known as 'Military' attacked civilians with machetes in Likoni (Mombasa) after one of theirs died in clashes with police (coded in a separate event), killing a Rwandan civilian in the process.

On 24 November 2018, a gang known as 'Military' engaged in a firefight with police as they were attacking civilians in Likoni (Mombasa). Police shot one gang member, who died later in hospital, and arrested seven. The gang members retaliated later against civilians (coded in separate event).

On 23 November 2018, a gang attacked a police officer on patrol in Ganjoni (Mombasa), seriously wounding the officer. The gang also robbed 5,000 KSH from the officer. The source indicates the victim was attacked with a machete.

On 23 November 2018, a police DCI shot and killed an unarmed junior officer following a dispute over a police car. He then attempted to shoot his uncle and fired at four bystanders, before retreating to a nearby police station, where he was disarmed and arrested by other police officers. The source does not specify the location, and coordinates for Thimbugua (Kiambu) have been used.

On 23 November 2018, a peaceful protest in Kitui town (Kitui) against alleged corruption by the county governor turned violent as the organising group - calling itself the Kitui County Youth Movement - clashed with a 'gang' arrived at the scene of the protest. Police dispersed the rioters using tear gas, and through firing live rounds in the air. A civilian was injured.

On 23 November 2018, police shot and wounded a man in Kusauni (Mombasa), accusing him of being involved in gang activities (a charge disputed by the victims family). It is not clear if the victim survived the incident, or died.

On 22 November 2018, clashes between the Kapkeny and Kabasiran clans broke out in the Mogil area (coordinates for Kapsowar, Elgeyo-Marakwet, used) leaving one person killed and two wounded. The sources states that the violence relates to a long-running land dispute.
On 21 November 2018, alleged bandits from Pokot attacked Chemisto village in Kipchumwa (Elgeyo-Marakwet) in a cattle raid. A child was shot in the hand during the attack.

On 20 November 2018, unknown gunmen attacked Chakama town (Kilifi), assaulting and abducting an Italian NGO volunteer, and firing at civilians as they left the town, wounding five (including four children). The identity of the attackers has not been established.

actor1: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Border Patrol Unit
notes: On 19 November 2018, the Police Border Patrol Unit repulsed an attack from Al Shabaab in or near the Boni forest of Ijara (Garissa county), killing either one or four fighters, and injuring several (coded as lowest etimate). There were no reports of casualties among the police.

On 19 November 2018, a 60 year-old woman was killed at Lira trading centre near the border between West Pokot and Elgeyo-Marakwet (coordinates for Kapenguria, West Pokot, used). The identity of the attackers is unknown, as is the motive, though the source suggests they are bandits.

On 17 November 2018, at an unspecified location along the Kisumu-Nandi border (coordinates for Chemase, Nandi, used), a farm manager was killed and her son seriously wounded following an attack by an unknown group. The source indicates the incident is part of a land dispute in the area, and also notes that the property belongs to a retired judge.

On 14 November 2018, boda boda (motorcycle) drivers in Isiolo town barricaded roads in protest against what they regarded as unfair targetting by police officers with respect to traffic law. Police fired teargas at the demonstrators.
On 16 November 2018, alleged bandits from Marakwet attacked the area of Chemusto in Pokot (coordinates for Kapenguria, West Pokot, used). During the raid, two of the suspected bandits were killed.
On 15 November 2018, after unknown gunmen killed a civilian in Sewes (Elgeyo-Marakwet, coordinates for Endo used), a police reservist responded to the distress call and was shot dead by the group.
On 15 November 2018, unknown gunmen killed a civilian in Sewes (Elgeyo-Marakwet, coordinates for Endo used). The source suggest they are bandits.

On 15 November 2018, a youth Pokot militia (whose members are reported to be between the ages of 10 and 14) shot and killed a herder at an unspecified location in Baringo North sub-county (Baringo, coordinates for Bartabwa used). The attackers fled the scene after the attack, stealing 22 head of cattle.

On 14 November 2018, a member of the Baringo county assembly was physically assaulted by other MCAs from the KANU party. The attackers locked the victim inside a room in the assembly building (in Kabarnet), before beating him up. Security guards broke down the down and rescued the victim, who was taken to hospital. The event was sparked by a dispute surrounding the public service board.

On 14 November 2018, the embattled governor of Migori - Okoth Obado - was once again arrested, following raids on his properties in Migori and Nairobi. Heavily armed officers entered the properties as part of an invesigation into alleged extensive corruption, and officers recovered eight firearms in the governor's houses. The governor is under investigation for the murder of his girlfriend in September.

During the week beginning 12th November (or shortly before), bandits killed a civilian at an unspecified location in Baringo North sub-county (Baringo, coordinates for Bartabwa used) and stole cattle.
On or after November 11th, demonstrators gathered in Kusauni and Nyali (Mobassa), to protest a spate of killings by a new gang in the area.
On or after November 11th, demonstrators gathered in Kusauni and Nyali (Mobassa), to protest a spate of killings by a new gang in the area.

On 10 November 2018, unknown gunmen shot at a Kenya Red Cross vehicle in Ruqa (Garissa, coordinates for Masalani used), wounding a volunteer travelling in the vehicle. Unverified possible connection with Al Shabaab.

On November 8th or 9th, the Matan and Geledle clans once again clashed, at an unspecified location in Wajir (coordinates for Wajir used). Three civilians, including a teenage girl, were killed in the violence.

On 7 November 2018, suspected Turkana raiders killed three police reservists and wounded two as they attempted to prevent them from stealing livestock at an unspecified location along the Igembe Central and Isiolo North border (coordinates for Isiolo town used).

On 7 November 2018, Matan and Geledle clans fought over a disputed joint settlement scheme in Qara (Wajir, coordinates for Kara Agarsu used, precision 2). One person was killed in the clash, and two injured.

On or before November 6th, residents of Kamasian (Kericho, coordinates for Kabirer used) barricaded the main road to protest against the presence of boulders, which the contracting company responsible for improving the road had not removed, and which are a potential danger to motorists. The demonstration was joined by a local politician.

On 6 November 2018, a civilian carrying charcoal was shot in the shoulder by a police officer in Magarini (Kilifi). The victim claimed that the officer had ordered him to stop, but he was shot even though he complied with the order (note that it is illegal to sell charcoal in the area).
On 6 November 2018, a police officer shot a fisherman at Naivasha (Nakuru), wounding him in the thigh. The police commander responsible for the area alleged that the fisherman was illegally fishing.

On 6 November 2018, clash between suspected pastoralists from Lagdera and Uchana communities in the area of Janju (Isiolo, close to Mado Gashi) in retaliation for earlier violence in the area.Three people died in the clash, including one 'raider' and two children, and an unknown number of people were wounded.

On or after November 6th, fishermen set fire to a boat owned by the Beach Management Unit of Naivasha (Nakuru), accusing security officers of usinge excessive force against a fisherman on November 6th.

On 4 November 2018, clash between suspected pastoralists from Lagdera and Uchana communities in Mado Gashi market (Isiolo) after an earlier 'botched raid' by the Lagdera in Mata Bofu. One person was injured.
On 4 November 2018, two people were wounded in a 'botched raid' at Mata Bofu, likey in Isiolo south. The attackers were believed to be pastoralists from Lagdera in Garissa county.

On 4 November 2018, students from Maseno University barricaded a road with fires and rocks near Maseno (Kisumu West, Kisumu) The demonstration was sparked by a separate incident involving students the previous day, and the manner in which the police handled that incident. [size=no report]

On 3 November 2018, clashes between pastoralist communities from Lagdera in Garissa county and Uchana in Isiollo. Two members of the Ladgera died in the skirmish, whilst two local militiamen were injured. It is unclear what caused the clash. This came amidst tensions in Garba Tula as approx 250 people displaced from Eldera over land were refusing to move from Garba Tula.

On or before November 2nd, two Maasai clans were reported to have clashed in Nkararo, Trans Mara West (coordinates for Trans Mara, Narok, used). Four people were injured by arrow fire, and police intervened to separate the groups. The source states that the clashes were part of a border dispute.

On 2 November 2018, residents of Butere gathered at Butere (Kakamega) to protest against a spate of killings and mutilations which are said to be the work of a gang known as the Forty Two Brothers. The protesters accused the police of failing to tackle the gang.

actor1: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Prison Guards
actor2: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Prison Guards
notes: On 2 November 2018, two senior prison officers assaulted another prison officer at Malindi prison (Kilifi). After pistol whipping the victim, they ran him over with a Land Cruiser. The victim survived, and is currently in hospital. Police are investigating the incident.
On or before October 31st, approximately 100 students marched to Kakamega South police station (coordinates for Kakamega used), to protest the sexual assault at Bushianga Technical College.

On 31 October 2018, suspected bandits attacked Kapkondot in Marakwet East (Elegeyo-Marakwet), seemingly to loot cattle. The bandits clashed with local police reservists, resulting in one fatality on the side of the bandits.

On 30 October 2018, a group of at least five men armed with machetes and hand weapons broke into Bushiangala Technical College, attacking and raping at least five students. A suspect has been arrested.

On 30 October 2018, armed cattle rustlers shot and killed an elderly woman at her home in Gathanji, after attempting to steal her two cows (coordinates for Ol Moran, Laikipia, used). Four suspects have been arrested.

On 29 October 2018, students from the Kaimosi Friends University College (Kaimosi) rioted in protest at increased fees, and delays in the payment of loans. Windows as well as a gate were damaged, and students clashed with police.
On or before October 28th, a gang attacked a motorbike taxi and gang-raped a female passenger, in the Dandora suburb of Nairobi.
On 28 October 2018, police tracked and shot dead six gang members suspected of raping a woman, in the Dandora suburb of Nairobi.

On 28 October 2018, a mob burned houses in several villages in Bomet county, in retaliation for the killing of a member of their community in a bar fight the previous day. In total, 16 dwellings were torched, all of which were the houses of relatives of the suspected killer.

On 26 October 2018, a gang shot and wounded a police officer during a failed robbery in the Mathare neighbourhood of Nairobi. The gang member was then killed by police, though two other suspects escaped the scene.

On or before October 25th, residents from the Katimokor area of Chepchoina (Trans Nzoia) protested against the mining operations of a Chinese firm, and the role of local authorities in granting the company permission to mine the area. The source indicates that the company is embroiled in a pre-existing land dispute in the area.

On or before October 24th, three herders (out of a group of seven) were killed and another injured when bandits fired upon them. The herders were making their way from Kapoa to Ameyan market (coordinates for Kapedo, Barringo, used).

On or before October 24th, teachers gathered in Litein (Kericho) to protest the killing of a colleague in July, and specifically the lack of police response to the murder. The source mentions that the 'demonstration turned violent as police dispersed the teachers from the streets' (the demonstrators have been coded as protesters rather than rioters, since it is not specified whether they engaged in violent activity).
On or before October 24th, demonstrators gathered in Machakos to protest against the poor condition of a road connecting Katangi to Matuu, and for the failure of local authorities to pave the road.
'A male staff member of an INGO was attacked by unknown assailants near his residence during the evening. The attack led to severe head injuries and a crack on his skull.'
On or before October 22nd, teachers gathered in Mbita (Homa Bay) to protest the murder of a colleague on October 13th, and the failure of police to arrest any suspects.
October 19th (on or before) police arrested 200 local residents described as 'suspects' after an earlier clash with gang members in Kayole.

On 19 October 2018, police clashed with an armed gang in Kayole (Nairobi). One gang member was killed, and a police officer is in critical condition after being shot in the head. Police were reported to have arrested 200 local residents, which the source described as 'suspects'.

On or before October 17th, two people were killed in a clash in Jaldesa (Marsabit), and two police reservists were wounded in the crossfire. The violence comes amidst recent ethnically-motivated clashes in the area. A number of local politicians have been questioned.

During the week beginning October 15th, clashes occurred at an unspecified location in Marsabit amidst ethnic violence. 10 killed (coded as 8 here and 2 for a clash in Jaldesa). Two local politicians were arrested on October 22nd over their alleged role in the violence.

On 17 October 2018, dozens of Nigerian citizens stormed the Nigerian High Commission in Nairobi, following the disapearence (and alleged killing) of a Nigerian citizen in police custody, and other (unconfirmed) recent deaths of Nigerians living in Kenya. The demonstration comes amidst a government crackdown on illegal immigration, which has resulted in a number of large scale arrests.

On 17 October 2018, students protested at the University of Machakos (Machakos), over a stipulation that they return to the University with their parents. The University closed indefinitely three weeks prior after student protests over an increase in fees. One person was arrested and later released.

On 16 October 2018, police fired their weapons into the air to scatter a crowd of protesters in Kisiwani (Kilifi). This followed the arrest of 40 people (including a local politician) for invading an area of disputed land.

On 16 October 2018, police arrested 40 people (including a local politician) over the invasion of a 900-acre Agricultural Development Corporation (ADC) land in Kisiwani, Kilifi County. The arrests took place in Kwa Ndomo in Sabaki ward.

On 16 October 2018, Al Shabaab militants alleged that they had destroyed two Kenyan military vehicles with an IED, killing and injuring an unspecified number of soldiers. The alleged incident took place between Fino and Arabiya villages in Mandera county (coordinates for Fino, Mandera, used). Subsequent reports indicate that the IED exploded before the military vehicles were in range, resulting in no casualties or fatalities.
On 12 October 2018, two robbery suspects were lynched by a mob in Kiptule area of Kericho West subcounty. The suspects were stoned to death after confessing their criminal activities.

On 12 October 2018, students from the Mombasa branch of the University of Nairobi protested the killing of a UoN student and another man by a mob on 7 Oct. The student was lynched in an alleged case of mistaken identity.

On 12 October 2018, a British-South African manager of the Olarro Nature Conservancy was shot in the head with an arrow at close range in Maji Moto (Narok). The attacker was wearing Maasai clothing. The manager fired two shots in the air, before escaping. He was patrolling near a disputed dam, that Maji Moto communities accused the conservationists of badly managing.

On 12 October 2018, an armed group attacked Shurr village in Marsabit county (coordinates for the state capital of Marsabit town used). In the ensuing gunfight, three residents of the town were killed, as was one of the attackers. The source describes the clash as being 'ethnic' in nature.
On 11 October 2018, residents of Jumba Ruins in Mtwapa, Mombasa county held a protest in the locality over the alleged grabbing of a 127-acre land they claim to own.

On 11 October 2018, bandits raided the village of Chemisto in Sigor constituency (coordinates for Sigor, West Pokot, used). They killed two civilian, including a child. The bandits also stole a significant amount of livestock. The attack comes three day after a truce was signed between the Pokot and Marakwet, which had been intended to put an end to such raiding and reprisal attacks.

On 11 October 2018, hundreds of South Sudanese residents in Kenya and Kenyans protested in Nairobi against the political and military elite of South Sudan, and the alleged complicity of individuals and economic institutions in Kenya in the process of such accumulation.They called upon the Kenyan government to seize wealth and assets that South Sudanese elites had stored in the Kenyan banking system.

On 10 October 2018, around twenty militants suspected to belong to Al Shabaab attacked a school in Lafey (Mandera). The militants targeted non-Muslim staff, and threw an explosive device into quarters used by non-Muslim teachers, killing two.
On or before October 9th, the residents of Tunen in Trans Nzoia (approximate coordinates used closed to the border with Uasin) protested against land grabbing in the area.

actor1: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Prison Guards
notes: On 9 October 2018, prison guards pursuing an escaped convict attacked 'dozens' of residents of a deprived neighbourhood in Nyeri. A prison official said that no reports of abuse had been filed.

On 9 October 2018, an armed group (described as bandits in the source) attacked the village of Nkiruni in Tharaka-North county (coordinates for county capital of Kathwana used). The group abducted a mother and her two daughters, and released two soon after. They also looted livestock from the area. [women targeted: girls]

On or around October 8th, around 1,000 protesters from Maji Moto bloked the Narok-Sikinani road, over a variety of disputes between the community and the Olarro Nature Conservancy, including the shooting of cattle and access to water sources. The Maasai community accused the conservancy of failing to constitute a proper management plan, to conduct elections of officials and a conservancy committee, and to review the land lease agreement.

On or before October 8th, residents of Siana ward protested following a dispute over grazing and access to water points with the Olarra Conservancy managing the game reserve. The protest took place at an unknown location (coordinates for Massai Mara Game Reserve used).
On 8 October 2018, a truce was signed between the Pokot and Marakwet to put an end to raiding and reprisal attacks.

On 7 October 2018, a 22 year old man was shot with arrows, and his corpse beheaded, by an unknown communal militia in the area of Mauche (Nakuru). There were over ten attackers, and four of the victim's friends were able to escape.

On 7 October 2018, a vigilante mob beat and set fire to two civilians who had been mistaken for thieves, as they left a drinking establishment in Mombassa. Both men (who were relatives) were killed in the attack.
On 6 October 2018, students gathered at the University of Kabianga (Kericho county) to protest against the killing of a fellow student, who had been found with stab wounds earlier that day.
On 5 October 2018, dozens of local residents staged a protest in Kutus town, Kirinyaga demanding the arrest of Josephine Kabura for lying in NYS affidavit.

On 5 October 2018, demonstrators barricaded roads in Gilgil town (Nakuru county), in protest at a spate of attacks and murders in the area. Riot police fired tear gas at the demonstrators, dispersing them.
On or before October 2nd, Kenyan security services fired at civilians in Madera county (precise location unspecified). At least one person was injured.

On 2 October 2018, during a violent demonstration at the county assembly at Homa Bay town (coded in a separate event), police assaulted a journalist from the Kenya Standard who was covering the demonstration.

On 2 October 2018, demonstrators broke into the county assembly at Homa Bay town amidst a political leadership dispute and threw stones at staff members. Police used tear gas to disperse the crowd. A journalist from the Kenya Standard who was covering the demonstration was assaulted by police during the event (coded in a separate event).
On or before October 2nd, Al Shabaab forces shelled a Kenyan military base in Mirarani (Lamu county). Casualties mentioned (unknown death or injuries coded as zero fatalaties).

On 1 October 2018, 12 gang members broke into a biscuit factory in Thika town (Kiambu county), and assaulted the security guards, before looting goods from the factory. Police arrived and shot six of the robbers dead, whilst six of the robbers fled the scene, apparently after all had sustained gunshot wounds. The police claimed that one of the gang members was in possession of a crude firearm.
On or before September 29th, protesters gathered at Jomvu (Mombasa) to demonstrate against land grabbing and the fraudlent sale of public land in the area.
27 September 2018: 2 people were reportedly killed by unidentified gunmen near Karasani town as they traveled to Lokori from Kapedo.

27 September 2018: Following an IED landmine attack the day before, Kenyen security forces raided the Daba city village in Mandara county and beat local residents with clubs and kicking them. At least 22 unarmed civilians were hurt during the event.

On 27 September 2018, matutu (minibus) drivers and local merchants protested the alleged failure of the police to investigate reports of Mungiki activity in Nairobi, who they have say have been extorting matatu operators, and were behind the recent murder of a matatu driver who refused to pay protection fees. Police denied the claims, saying they arrested several gang members.
26 September 2018: An IED hit a Kenyan military vehicle in Daba-city village in Mandera County.

From September 24th - 26th, students demonstrated against fee increases at the University of Machakos (Machokos). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas on Monday 24th; arrested a student leader on the 25th; and again dispersed protesters on the 26th (the source does not specify how). The University was indefinitely closed as of Sep 26th.

On 26 September 2018, two children were killed near Nakuyen village, North Pokot after they touched and played with a RDX explosive device, which exploded. The device had been left in the area by the military who had conducted an operation locally.

On 25 September 2018, residents of Githurai town, Kiambu, staged road blocks and set up bonfires on Thika Superhighway in protest against the police's slow response to remove debris and bodies following a road accident in the area. Youth allegedly hurled stones at the police who arrived later and used tear gas to disperse them.

From September 24th - 26th, students demonstrated against fee increases at the University of Machakos (Machokos). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas on Monday 24th; arrested a student leader on the 25th; and again dispersed protesters on the 26th (the source does not specify how). The University was indefinitely closed as of Sep 26th.
25 September 2018: Al-Shabaab forces reportedly killed a Kenyan soldier in Lamu county (location unspecified by the source).

On 25 September 2018, a pro-Al Shabaab radio station reported that Al Shabaab forces had attacked a KDF camp at Taksile, north of Lamu (coordinates for Lamu used). According to the source, 10 KDF soldiers were killed, and three Al Shabaab fighters were also killed.

24 September 2018: Al-Shabaab militants claim to have overrun a Kenyan military base in Taksile area north of Pandaguo, Lamu County, killing 10 Kenyan soldiers and admitting three deaths among their own ranks. Kenyan military sources also reported the clashes, although they claimed that 10 Al-Shabaab fighters had been killed. Fatalities coded at the most conservative estimate.

From September 24th - 26th, students demonstrated against fee increases at the University of Machakos (Machokos). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas on Monday 24th; arrested a student leader on the 25th; and again dispersed protesters on the 26th (the source does not specify how). The University was indefinitely closed as of Sep 26th.

On 24 September 2018, KDF soldiers attacked an Al Shabaab hideout at Taksile, north of Lamu (coordinates for Lamu used), killing 10 Al Shabaab fighters, and seizing weapons and ammunition. 3 KDF soldiers were reported to have been injured in the attack and weapons were recovered.

On 25 September 2018, Kipsigi and Maasai militias clashed at Olpusimo (Narok). Seven people were injured in arrow fire, and 10 dwellings were torched. Police intervened to separate the two groups, and security has been increased in the area.

On 23 September 2018, around 400 Maasai demonstrators protested against a planned eviction from farmland whose ownership is contested by members of the Maasai and Kikyu communities. The event occurred at Mai Mahiu

On 22 September 2018, local labourers of a Chinese company contracted to lay tarmac on Suguta-Maralal road staged a protest in front of Sino Hydro's office in Maralal town denouncing poor working conditions and non-payment of overtime.
On or before September 21st, police shot dead a matutu (minibus) tout in Dandora (Nairobi), sparking protests on Sep 21st. There are no further details on the incident.
21 September 2018: Armed men from Marakwet village reportedly raided the Ng'oron village, Tirioko Tiaty Sub-county. According to the report, three people were killed and several others injured.
On 21 September 2018, the police shot dead a youth in Dandora who was allegedly smoking marihuana (bhang). The police stated that the incident occurred due to the youth possessing a weapon.

On 21 September 2018, a herder militia (believed to be Somali in ethnicity) attacked Muthungwe village (coordinates for Mutitu, Kitui, used). The group killed a man and seriously injured his wife, using machetes to do so. The motive for the attack is not clear.

On 21 September 2018, demonstrators - comprising youth and matutu operators - clashed with police in Dandora (Nariobi), with police using tear gas to scatter the protesters. The demonstrations were related to the shooting of a matutu tout by police.

On 21 September 2018, a gang of five men ambushed three people as they returned to Koromangucha village from a party in a nearby village (coordinates for Kuria East, Migori, used). One person was killed, and two others were wounded before they escaped. The attackers used machetes; there was no clear motive for the attack.

On 20 September 2018, a suspected bandit shot dead two herders and a child in Kerio Valley or nearby area as a revenge for the family failing to share cows stolen by one of the victims and the perpetrator during a raid in Tiaty, Baringo county. The attacker later surrendered to the police.
On 20 September 2018, an unspecified group burned 20 shops and an unknown number of houses in Nessuit village (Nakuru).

On September 18th and 19th, a criminal gang attacked Ragumo and Ofunyu villages in Kisumu East constituency (coordinates for Nyamasaria, Kisumu used). The group assaulted an unspecified number of residents, and engaged in multiple counts of theft.

19 September 2018: The Mombasa/Nairobi highway was blocked by protesting Matatu drivers from Mikindani to the Central Business District, Jomvu, Mombasa. The drivers protested the lack of parking space within the city. At least one person was arrested. The protests come as the Mikindani stage was shut down the night before by police officers armed with batons and tear gas.
On 19 September 2018, the police allegedly shot dead three youth in Dandora who were reportedly smoking marihuana (bhang).

On 19 September 2018, around 1,000 workers at the Mumias Sugar Company (Kakamega) blockaded roads around the factory, in protest at the non-payment of salaries for 17 months, and alleged mismanagement at the firm.

On or around September 18th, an unidentified group carrying axes and machetes attacked and robbed the uncle of a murder victim, which is connected to the Governor of Migori county. The event happened in Nairobi, and the victim was able to fend off the attackers.

On September 18th and 19th, a criminal gang attacked Ragumo and Ofunyu villages in Kisumu East constituency (coordinates for Nyamasaria, Kisumu used). The group assaulted an unspecified number of residents, and engaged in multiple counts of theft.
On 18 September 2018, residents from Mitahato village in Githunguri blocked the Kirigiti-Kwamaiko road in protest over poor workmanship carried out on the road by the contractor.

On 18 September 2018, activists demonstrated in Meru town demanding justice for Githongo law court magistrate's daughter who had been abducted and killed. The protesters also demanded an overhaul of local police units and better security.
On 17 September 2018, a bread vendor was shot dead by the police near an armory at the AP line in Kigumo.

On 17 September 2018, protesters from the Jubilee Party marched in Nakuru, in the hope of changing the county-level leadership of the party. The protesters attempted to storm the HQ of the county branch of the party, but were unable to gain access to the premises, which was reported to be deserted.
On 16 September 2018, the perpetrator of a fatal stabbing of a local teacher was beaten to death by a crowd at the outskits of Limuru town.
On 16 September 2018, 'heavily-armed' Ugandan police deployed to the disputed island of Migingo, prompting Kenyan fishermen to avoid sailing near the island.

At some point during the middle of September, two communal militias clashed in the village of Oronderi in Marsabit county (coordinates for the state capital of Marsabit town used), reportedly over a land dispute. No further detail is provided in the source.
At an unspecified time (likely on or after mid-September, precision 3 used) the Mungiki sect reportedly murdered a matatu (minibus) operator in Nairobi, after he refused to pay them protection money.
On 15 September 2018, suspected Pokot militiamen shot and wounded three police officers in an ambush in Ramacha, Baringo South.
On 15 September 2018, a man shot dead his neighbour in Irobo village, Shinyalu, Kakamega county following a land dispute.

14 September 2018: Several shops and homes were burned to the ground in the Musegekwa village, Njoro county, despite a police curfew in the town as a result of ethnic violence. Coordinates given for Nessuit village, which is nearby.

14 September 2018: A body has been found dumped in a pit latrine in Musegekwa village, Njoro county (coordinates given for Nessuit, which is nearby), most likely a result of ethnic violence that has troubled the area for some time. The victim left his house to graze his animals and was shot shortly after.

14 September 2018: Three people were reportedly killed by Police forces in the Musegekwa village, Njoro county, as police attempted to halt ethnic violence in the area. Coordinates given for Nessuit village, which is nearby.

On 14 September 2018, a local militia fired arrows at police in Nessuit (Njoro, Nakuru). Police then fired at the attackers, killing one. Several arrests took place that day, including of the Deputy Speaker of the county, and two tribal chiefs. The events are part of ongoing violence in the area.
On 14 September 2018, eight Al Shabaab gunmen ambushed a bus near Ijara, heading to Garissa. They profiled people travelling on the bus and killed two non-local passengers.
On or before September 13th, clashes took place in Ndoswa (Nakuru, approximate coordinates used), with a number of Ogiek buildings burnt. There were no reports of injuries or deaths.

13 September 2018: Police forces opened fire at rioters throwing rocks at police officers in the town of El Wak, killing at least one person. Rioters then entered the hospital compound and attacked non-locals, killing two and seriously injuring a third. They were demonstrating against the death of three people who they said were killed by security officers a day before. Coded as two separate events, one riot and one VAC event.

13 September 2018: Police forces opened fire at rioters throwing rocks at police officers in the town of El Wak, killing at least one person. Rioters then entered the hospital compound and attacked non-locals, killing two and seriously injuring a third. They were demonstrating against the death of three people who they said were killed by security officers a day before. Coded as two separate events, one riot and one VAC event.

On 13 September 2018, a police officer fatally assaulted a minibus driver with his rifle. A mob formed and chased the police officer, lynching him. Another man (a boda boda driver) was killed in the violence. The events took place in the area of Kenyenya (Kisii), and a police Internal Affairs Unit has been dispatched to investigate.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-); Taxi Drivers (Kenya)
notes: On 13 September 2018, a police officer fatally assaulted a minibus driver with his rifle. A mob formed and chased the police officer, lynching him. Another man (a boda boda driver) was killed in the violence. The events took place in the area of Kenyenya (Kisii), and a police Internal Affairs Unit has been dispatched to investigate. [size=no report]
On 13 September 2018, armed men attacked and killed a Nyumba Kumi official, an unarmed community watch officer associated with police, at Barsheba area in Kisauni, Mombasa.
On 13 September 2018, a mob accosted and lynched a suspected political militiaman whose group had been accused of causing mayhem in Junda area, Kisauni, Mombasa.

On 13 September 2018, further clashes were reported between the Ogiek and Kipsigi groups in Nessuit, Eastern Mau Forest (Nakuru, coordinates for Mau Narok used). One person was killed, and more houses were torched.

On 13 September 2018, a police officer beat a minibus driver with his rifle, killing the man. A mob formed and chased the police officer, lynching him, and another man (a boda boda driver) was killed in the violence. The events took place in the area of Kenyenya (Kisii), and a police Internal Affairs Unit has been dispatched to investigate.

During the week beginning September 10th, police shot dead three young men working on a dumpsite in Dandora (Nairobi). The police claimed one of the individuals was a notorious gangster, and that the deceased had been armed. The events have been contested by the family of one of the victims, who said that he worked at the dumpsite, and was not a robber.

12 September 2018: Security forces reportedly arrested a family of 5 in the town of El-Wak. Three of those arrested were later found dead, and local civilians have accused security forces of being responsible for their deaths.

On September 11th and 12th, armed clashes were reported in the Nessuiet, Mariashoni, Mauche, and other wards of Njoro county (Nakuru) between the Ogiek and Kipsigi groups, which resulted in 6 deaths (coded across 6 events) and 17 injuries. Houses were also torched in the clashes. The identities of the victims are not known. The clashes are likely spillover from violence in neighbouring Narok that flared up after a dispute over livestock theft and occupation of land on the edges of the Mau Forest.

On September 11th and 12th, armed clashes were reported in the Nessuiet, Mariashoni, Mauche, and other wards of Njoro county (Nakuru) between the Ogiek and Kipsigi groups, which resulted in 6 deaths (coded across 6 events) and 17 injuries. Houses were also torched in the clashes. The identities of the victims are not known. The clashes are likely spillover from violence in neighbouring Narok that flared up after a dispute over livestock theft and occupation of land on the edges of the Mau Forest.

Houses were also torched in the clashes. The identities of the victims are not known. The clashes are likely spillover from violence in neighbouring Narok that flared up after a dispute over livestock theft and occupation of land on the edges of the Mau Forest.
On 12 September 2018, informal traders staged a demonstration along Diani Beach Road in Kwale, protesting the ongoing demolition of their stalls ordered by the county government.

On 12 September 2018, two men were killed in Kilolapwa and Shamu villages in the area of Ukunda (Kwale county). The victim in Kololapwa was an imam, who had been known to encourage youth not to join fundamentalist Islamic groups. Al Shabaab are suspected, but not confirmed, to have been involved in the deaths, which were within thirty minutes of each other.

On 12 September 2018, police killed two suspected gang members who had been active in the Juja area, at Karuguru close to the Eastern Bypass (coordinates for Juja, Kiambu, used). Eight gang members escaped.

On September 11th and 12th, armed clashes were reported in the Nessuiet, Mariashoni, Mauche, and other wards of Njoro county (Nakuru) between the Ogiek and Kipsigi groups, which resulted in 6 deaths (coded across 6 events) and 17 injuries. Houses were also torched in the clashes. The identities of the victims are not known. The clashes are likely spillover from violence in neighbouring Narok that flared up after a dispute over livestock theft and occupation of land on the edges of the Mau Forest.

Houses were also torched in the clashes. The identities of the victims are not known. The clashes are likely spillover from violence in neighbouring Narok that flared up after a dispute over livestock theft and occupation of land on the edges of the Mau Forest.

Houses were also torched in the clashes. The identities of the victims are not known. The clashes are likely spillover from violence in neighbouring Narok that flared up after a dispute over livestock theft and occupation of land on the edges of the Mau Forest.

On 11 September 2018, activists staged a protest in Nairobi against the murder of a Rongo University student who had been abducted together with the journalist Barrack Oduor. The protesters called on politicians to act upon the recent killing.

On 11 September 2018, a police vehicle belonging to the Anti-Stock Theft Unit was hit by an explosion in Kotulo ward (Wajir). They began searching for suspects afterwards. There were no reports of police injuries or deaths.

On 11 September 2018, police apprehended four members of the same family at Qababa village in Elram (Kotulo ward, Wajir). One was beaten before being released, and the other three were found dead the following day. All had been shot in the head. The police were conducting a search operation in the area following an attack on a police vehicle the same day.

On 10 September 2018, matatu (minibus) operators blocked traffic on Murang'a - Kiriaini road in protest against the roads' dilapidated state. They demanded the road be re-carpeted instead of the government only investing in filling potholes.

On 10 September 2018, the police allegedly shot dead a young man in Mtongwe, Mombasa following a raid in his home. The killing was done reportedly as part of the police's manhunt for a gang that has been attacking civilians in the local area.

On 10 September 2018, three people - including a 17 year old boy - were wounded at a field near Mauche (Nakuru). The attackers, who were believed to come from a nearby (unspecified) community, fired arrows at the civilians. It is probable that this event is connected to violence in neighbouring Narok area.

On 10 September 2018, a 13 year old boy was hacked to death, and his 12 year old sister and 70 year old grandmother were wounded in the attack in Esimenwa village (coordinates for Narok town used). The attack follows violence between the Maasai and Kipsigi groups in the area the following week (which some reports attribute to conflicts over land titles, some to cattle rustling, and others to actions by the government and/or assorted local politicians), though the specific identity of the group of attackers is not specified in the source, nor is the ethnicity of the victims. Police have been deployed to the area, and a suspect has been arrested.

Arrests: During the week leading up to 8th September, Kenyan police reportedly arrested 163 Pakistani nationals in the city of Mombasa, as part of a nation-wide crackdown on illegal immigration. On September 5th, police also raided the offices of the China Global Television Network in Nairobi, arresting 13 Chinese civilians (including journalists).
On or around 7 Sept 2018, tribal clashes erupted in Marsabit county following the recent killing of two people near Maasai Mau forest in Narok county.

07 September. Two days of clashes took place on September 6th and 7th in Olmekenyu (Narok county), between Maasai and Kipsigi militias, seemingly in response to the murder of a herder on September 4th. Two people were killed in the clashes (which involved spears and bows and arrows), and at least thirteen injured, whilst a significant amount of property was torched and cattle looted (the deaths have been split over two events). Police attempted to separate the groups, and used tear gas at one point. Subsequent reports have suggested the violence has its roots in land disputes and/or involvement of local politicians, which have been exacerbated by incidents of theft.

Two days of clashes on or before September 6th in Olmekenyu (Narok county), between Maasai and Kipsigi militias, seemingly in response to the murder of a herder on September 4th. Two people were killed in the clashes (which involved spears and bows and arrows), and thirteen injured, whilst a significant amount of property was torched (the deaths have been split over two events). Police attempted to separate the groups, and used tear gas at one point.

On 6 September 2018, a man was shot with an arrow during a suspected revenge mission in Nkoben area near Maasai Mau forest in Narok county following the killing in the same area on 4 Sept. Tension in the community was high following the incidents.
On 6 September 2018, police killed three youth who they said were suspected criminals at Utage (Mombasa county). Police dismissed claims that these were extra-judicial killings.

On 5 September 2018, two people were killed following armed clashes between Gabra and Borana pastoralist militia over pasture in Horonder, between Moyale and Marsabit. The first person died during clashes on 5 Sept, while the second passed away the following morning. Three other people were wounded.

On or before September 4th, off-duty Kenyan police officers demanded bribes from civilians drinking at an illicit brewery in Sondu (Kericho). After detaining several civilians, a crowd formed to release them, and the police fired gunshots to disperse the crowd, wounding a bystander. Senior police are reported to be investigating the incident.

On or before September 4th, police killed three men suspected of murdering a local chief, in Kanyagia village (Nyeri county). Police activities against political militias have been stepped up in the area.

On 4 September 2018, drivers were reported to have blocked roads in the area of Mt. Kenya (locations not specified, coordinates for Nyeri town used). This was in protest at the introduction of a (long-delayed) fuel tax.

On 4 September 2018, drivers were reported to have blocked part of the Kisii-Bomet highway (location not specified, coordinates for Bomet used). This was in protest at the introduction of a (long-delayed) fuel tax.

On 4 September 2018, a herder (of an unspecified ethnicity) was killed in the Nkoben area of the Maasai Mau forest (coordinates for Mau Narok used). This killing sparked two days of violence in Narok (see separate entries).

On or before September 3rd, armed gangsters raided a petrol station in Oyugis town (Homa Bay district). The two security guards at the station had their hands tied, and an unspecified amount of money was stolen. Two of the robbers were wearing police uniforms and carry AKs, whilst the remaining six were not.

On or before September 3rd, a militia comprising traders from the Maasai ethnic group attacked traders at Muthurwa market in Narok Town and set fire to the market, following the destruction of Maasai stalls by the local government. The Maasai were said to be armed, whilst the traders they were attacking used machetes to defend themselves. One person (from an unspecified group) was killed, and seven were injured. Police were also attacked once they became involved.
On or before September 3rd, traders from the Maasai ethnic group demonstated against the demolition of their stalls in Uhuru market by authorities in Narok Town.

On or before September 3rd, herders grazing their cattle in Boni Forest (Garissa county) were reportedly detained and beaten by the Kenyan military. At least eight herders were beaten, some seriously, and they have been separated from their cattle. The KDF denied that it was conducted any operations in the area.

On or before September 3rd, Ugandan maritime police pursued Kenyan fisherman to Sumba island (Busia district), after they had allegedly been fishing in Ugandan waters. Upon reaching the island, Kenyan residents and fisherman threw stones at the Ugandan police, who fired shots in the air, before leaving. The residents of the island appealed to the Kenyan government to establish a police post on the island.

On 3 September 2018, a gang hired to evict a family (as part of a land dispute) were attacked by vigilantes, who killed one gang member. The incident took place at Kagumo-ini village (Muranga, coordinates for Kabati used).

On 4 September 2018, around 1,000 residents of Kiambu (Mbeere South) marched to Gitaru power station in protest at the lack of adequate water availability (which they attributed to KenGen's dam-building activities). The protesters blockaded two roads in the area, damaged railings, and set fire to tires. Police prevented them from entering the power station itself.
On 3 September 2018, around 120 youth from Makueni county blocked the Machakos-Wote road in protests at unpaid wages for their work in upgrading work in the county (coordinates for Wote used).
On 3 September 2018, residents of Ngecha village (Kiambu county) demonstrated against a local gang known as the 'Gaza Boys'.

On 3 September 2018, a journalist and a pregnant University student were abducted in Migori. After being attacked, the journalist escaped the moving car he was in, sustaining serious injuries. The student's body was later found in a forest, having been stabbed multiple times, and likely raped. The personal assistant of Governor Okoth Obado has been arrested for allegdly orchestrating the kidnap and murder. Obado was himself charged with aiding and abetting the murder on September 24th.
On 3 September 2018, drivers of taxis, matatus and boda bodas barricaded roads in Nakuru town, in protest at the increase in fuel tax which came into effect that day.

On 30 August 2018, a group of activists held a peaceful protest in Mombasa over the disappearance of a local youth. They also raised concerns over the rising number of forced disappearances in the region.

On 30 August 2018, local clan members torched 14 houses in Kapyego, Marakwet East as an act of revenge towards the relatives of the man suspected to have shot dead an area acting chief. The chief had been shot dead by herders on suspicion he was a cattle thief.

On 29 August 2018, five Kenyan soldiers were killed and ten wounded when their vehicle hit a landmine on the road between Kiunga and Sankuri (Lamu, coordinates for Kiunga used). It was not clear who had planted the device, though a pro-Al Shabaab radio station in Somalia subsequently claimed that Al Shabaab had killed at least 20 Kenyan soldiers in an (unverified) attack in the area of Lamu, which was reported to be an ambush. Until further information comes to light, this has been coded as a single event of remote violence by an unknown group, killing five.

Arrests: On August 28th, the Deputy Chief Justice of Kenya - Philomena Mwilu - was arrested on corruption and tax evasion charges, and released on bail. The move follows tensions between the presidency and the judiciary regarding the elections in 2017.

Between approximately 23 Aug and 6 Sept 2018, a suspect in the attempted murder of a former Garissa Finance executive claimed he had been tortured in custody by the police (where he had been for 15 days) and subjected to inhumane conditions while in Gigiri police station. The detainee is allegedly in need of medical attention.

On 28 August 2018, protestors barricaded the road between Emali and Wote (Makueni sub-county, coordinates for Emali used). The demonstrators were angry about the substandard condition of the road, and the failure of the three MPs of the region to address their concerns.

On or before August 27th, around 300 protesters gathered in Chepkositonik (Bomet County) to demonstrate against a poor quality bridge that had been built by the government in the village, and an alleged misappropriation of funds surrounding the construction project.

Arrests: On or before August 27th, counter-terror police arrested seven individuals suspected of being affiliated to Al Shabaab, in Ijara sub-county (Garissa county). Three of the suspects were later released.
On or before August 27th, protestors in Kiambere (Embu County, approximate coordinates used) demonstrated against KenGen's failure to supply the area with clean drinking water, and electricity.

On August 27th or 28th, a police officer killed a suspected drug dealer, who had been arrested and taken to the police station, before being shot in the head (note that his death took place on Moses Mudavadi road, and that the source does not specify the circumstances). The police officer in question has been arrested in connection with the killing.

On 27 August 2018, two groups clashed at the water plant in Muranga (coordinates for Muranga county used), with one group damaging the water supply at the plant. The dispute appears to centre around a grudge between the governor of Muranga County and the outgoing chairman of the water plant.

On 27 August 2018, angry residents stormed the hospital in Malindi sub-county following the death of a man involved in a vehicle accident to protest alleged negligence on the part of the medical staff of the hospital. The staff denied.
On or before August 26th, police killed five gang members in the Dandora area of Nairobi. The police ambushed the gang members following a tip-off, and seized weapons and cannabis.
On or before August 26th, police killed a gang member in the Lucky Summer neighbourhood of Nairobi, following a failed robbery attempt on a matutu. Three gang members escaped.
On 26 August 2018, a matatu driver was wounded in Bomet after a police officer allegedly knocked out his teeth for refusing to accept a bribe.

Property destruction: on August 24th, and according to an Al Shabaab commander, the group destroyed power stations in Lamu town and Tana River town (for the latter, the location of Hola has been used). There has been no confirmation of this claim in other sources.

Property destruction: on August 24th, and according to an Al Shabaab commander, the group destroyed power stations in Lamu town and Tana River town (for the latter, the location of Hola has been used). There has been no confirmation of this claim in other sources.
On 23 August 2018, dozens of protestors gathered in Nairobi's Uhuru park, demanding the release of Ugandan MP Bobi Wine, who is in detention in Kampala.

On 22 August 2018, motorists of the Kenya Motorists Association staged a demonstration in Roysambu, Nairobi against the proposed 16% Value Added Tax on petroleum. The protest was allegedly aborted soon after starting.

On or before August 20th, a confrontation broke out between the crowd and police at a funeral for the driver of an MP (who was targeted in an assassination attempt on August 12th, when his driver was killed), after a County executive made an unwelcome appearence. Five were injured, including two bodyguards of other MPs and a local politician.

On 20 August 2018, protesters gathered in Chebunyo (Bomet county) and blocked vehicles from leaving a nearby quarry. They were demonstrating against the marginalisation of Chebunyo and the poor state of the road running through the area (and the use of quarry materials in areas other than Chebunyo).

On 19 August 2018, three men attacked the former finance county executive of Garissa county, as he was returning home from a mosque in Kilelshwa (Nairobi). The victim was shot in the head at close range, and was critically injured. On August 28th, the Governor of Garrissa - Ali Korane - was arrested and questioned by police in relations to the incident. He was released but remained a person of interest. Three other suspects were arrested, one of whom reportedly committed suicide.

On 18 August 2018, merchants in Mombasa protested against the seizure of a consignment of sugar by the police, leading to a stand-off between the protesters and the police. The Somali Community Traders chairman reported that 50 shops had been raided by the police, and that the police were extorting shopkeepers.
On 16 August 2018, a public service vehicle travelling from Elwak to Mandera was attacked by unidentified gunmen. Three passengers were left in a critical condition.

During the month of August, four people were murdered in the sub-district of Butere (Kakamega county), reportedly by a local gang named 'The 42 Brothers'. The precise times for three of the murders are not specified.

During the month of August, four people were murdered in the sub-district of Butere (Kakamega county), reportedly by a local gang named 'The 42 Brothers'. The precise times for three of the murders are not specified.

During the month of August, four people were murdered in the sub-district of Butere (Kakamega county), reportedly by a local gang named 'The 42 Brothers'. The precise times for three of the murders are not specified.
On 14 August 2018, a civilian was murdered in the sub-district of Butere (Kakamega county), reportedly by a local gang named 'The 42 Brothers'.
On 13 August 2018, three border wall workers were killed after their vehicle ran over an Improvised Explosive Device. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility. Another source reported tens of fatalities.
On 12 August 2018, armed men shot and killed the driver of an MP at Soy Highway Motel in Kakamega county as they came in looking for the MP.
On 11 August 2018, a 13-year-old girl was beaten to death by six Pokot youths in Nasorot village, Tiaty subcounty, Baringo county for refusing to marry a 60-year-old man. [women targeted: girls]
On 9 August 2018, a young thief has been lynched by a mob after he had stolen a mobile phone. They hit him with stones which led to his death.
Arrests: On 8 August, Evans Kidero, former Nairobi governor, was arrested alongside Lilian Wanjiru, Jimmy Mutuku and other influential businessmen and politicians.
On 8 August 2018, five Kenyan soldiers were killed and six others wounded when their vehicle was blown up by an IED near the town of Bodhei. Al-Shabaab claimed the attack.
On 8 August 2018, people who were evicted from illegally constructed homes and civil society activists staged a protest in Nairobi against the recent governmental campaign to destroy illegal housing.

On 6-7 August, business and transport was paralysed at Namanga border town as Kenyans barricaded the main road and deflated the tires of lorries to protest mistreatment by Tanzanian authorities after several milk traders were arrested and placed in custody in Tanzania. Traders on both sides of the border incurred big losses.

7 August 2018: Three Somali herders who were grazing their cows on a planted land in Ganze, Kilifi County reportedly attacked the land-owner with knives, seriously injuring him and his brother who came to his aid.
On 7 August 2018, a suspected thief has been lynched by a mob after he had broken into a house and stole a laptop and two mobile phones. The mob beat him up and set him on fire.
08 June. A vigilante mob at Nangili market in Likuyani lynched a motorcycle thief.
Security measures: On 6 August, a new police border patrol unit with camels has been established to patrol remote sections of the Kenya-Somali border in Isiolo County.

On 6-7 August, business and transport was paralysed at Namanga border town as Kenyans barricaded the main road and deflated the tires of lorries to protest mistreatment by Tanzanian authorities after several milk traders were arrested and placed in custody in Tanzania. Traders on both sides of the border incurred big losses.

assoc_actor_1: KNUN: Kenya National Union of Nurses; Health Workers (Kenya)
notes: On 6 August 2018, Kenya National Union of Nurses (KNUN) demonstrated at the Bomet County HQs demanding to be paid their June and July salaries.

assoc_actor_1: KUDHEIHA: Kenya Union of Domestic, Hotels, Educational Institutions, Hospital and Allied Workers; Health Workers (Kenya)
notes: On 6 August 2018, police used teargas to disperse striking staff of Kenyatta National Hospital in Nairobi who protested over non-payment of their health service allowances.
On 6 August 2018, residents of Kajiado blocked Namanga Highway at Ilbisil (Bissil) town, Kajiado county to protest alleged handing over of Kenyan criminal suspects to Tanzanian authorities.

On 5 August 2018, unsatisfied worshippers at the African Independent Penecostal Church of Africa in Nyandarua blocked access to the Uiguano Rurii Church and verbally ejected the visiting bishop out of the church in a conflict over the legitimacy of the bishop.
On 2 August 2018, over 80 traders were arrested in the Lavington and Kawangware areas (Kilimani, Nairobi) in an operation against illegal structures. The demolitions are expected to continue.
31 July. Ethiopian Merrile militia shoots and kills Todonyang chief Ekal Lochamin in Lowerangak. The militia were believed to be cattle bandits.

On 31 July 2018, a prison warden shot and wounded an inspectorate officer in Mombasa. The perpetrator became hostile after he committed a traffic offense in busy traffic, shooting the officer. The public retaliated by lynching the perpetrator.

27 July. The mother of a Kenyan man, who allegedly mutilated his wife, is stoned to death by a mob in Jerusalem village of Kirinyaga County. The woman was targeted the vigilantes suspected she was hiding her son. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]
26 July. Al Shabaab fighters ambush a group of police in Milihoi. One dead, two injured. Security forces added personnel to the region in response.
23 July. Hundreds of Narok residents marched peacefully to protest calls by some politicians for Mau Forest evictions not to take place.

20 July. Several students of Kanjuri Boys High School in Mathira, Nyeri were injured during a confrontation with villagers and police who thwarted their attempt to burn a school building. The students were possibly angered over the arraignment of several other protesting students.

Property destruction: 20 July. A former Member of County Assembly's house was set ablaze by unknown assailants. The arson attack occurred three days before the High Court was to deliver a ruling in an election petition between him and the current MCA Wilson Kuyo.
19 July. Shop owners protest insecurity in Molo town.
18 July. The Transport Chief Administrative Secretary's driver is shot and killed in Kariobangi for unknown reason.
Week of 16 July. Students of Munyeki primary school in Ol Kalou protest after donated clothes do not fit. Exact date of the protest is not known.
